search_result.title: No Firefly? These 9 Delaware events will fill the gap
search_result.text:
It's no secret Firefly Music Festival will be sorely missed this year.

Although organizers said the event will come back in 2024, its cancellation begs the question: What do you have to look forward to in Delaware in the meantime?

Whether you want to run in underwear with strangers, get chased by a bull or watch chefs duke it out against each other for your benefit, there are a lot of fun events you can dive into in 2023, even if you can't vibe out at The Woodlands.

Here's a snapshot of what to expect.

Lewes Polar Plunge

The icy sensation of getting blasted by cold water in the shower doesn’t compare to the tingling sensation you’ll feel after you’ve plunged into the Atlantic during the winter.

But what makes it really fun is you’ll be joined by hordes of other thrill seekers of all ages, plenty of whom will be dressed in polar bear attire. All of this is in the name of supporting the Special Olympics Delaware through the fundraiser event. The Lewes Polar Plunge, now in its 32nd year, attracts people from far beyond Delaware.

Participants who can’t make it in person can still donate and do a virtual plunge (which can be done anywhere, any time). Additionally, lots of cool events will be held the weekend of the plunge. But diving into the arctic water is the main event.

Lewes Beach (206 Bay Ave., Lewes) at 1 p.m. Sunday, Feb. 5. Registration is $75 through midnight on Tuesday, Jan. 31; Beginning Wednesday, Feb. 1, it increases to $100. Visit plungede.org or (302) 831-4653

‘Avenue Q,’ Middletown

Imagine watching a musical about adulthood told through puppets with potty mouths.

Welcome to the rated-R production “Avenue Q.”

It’s a comedic Tony-winning musical that follows a college grad who moves into a rundown New York apartment in Avenue Q.

While his neighbors appear normal, the graduate eventually learns he’s in a strange place. To make matters worse, the man and his buddies find it challenging to land dates and keep jobs.

This show is for adults only.

The Everett (47 W. Main St., Middletown). The first of six shows starts at 7:30 p.m. Friday, Feb. 10. Final show is at 2 p.m., Sunday, Feb. 19. Tickets are $22. For more info, visit everetttheatre.com or (302) 378-7038.

Wilmington Cupid's Fun Run

It’s socially acceptable to nonchalantly run in your underwear in the cold, as long you’re doing to it raise funds for NF Research and the Children's Tumor Foundation.

Wilmington Cupid's Fun Run begins with a half-mile run/walk that ends in a party.

Participants are encouraged to run/walk in their skimmies to raise awareness for neurofibromatosis, a genetic disorder that causes tumors to grow on the body.

Since individuals with NF can’t hide their tumors, Cupid runners have chosen to take off their clothes in support.

DECO Wilmington (111 W. 10th St., Wilmington) at noon Saturday, Feb. 25. You can make a donation at my.cupids.org/event/2023-wilmington-cupids-fun-run.

Wilmington Flower Market

Last spring was special because it marked the return of the Wilmington Flower Market after it was missing for two years due to COVID-19 cancellations.

Despite its name, there’s much more to love than just flowers at this event. There are rides for kids, food trucks and live music. Last May, the new James Malick Stage debuted, featuring a lineup curated by Gable Music Ventures.

Over the years, the Flower Market has attracted a few acts from Firefly Music Festival. Hopefully, they’ll bring back some Firefly alum this year.

Proceeds from the Wilmington Flower Market benefit children’s charities in Delaware.

Rockford Park (W. 19th St. and Tower Road, Wilmington). Dates and lineup haven’t been announced yet. For more info, visit wilmingtonflowermarket.org.

Point-to-Point, Winterthur

Dust off your wide-brim hats (and maybe bring an umbrella) for more steeple-chasing excitement at the 45th annual Point-to-Point.

Tailgating at this Winterthur classic isn’t an option. It’s a way of life.

In addition to the races, vendors, community organizations, parades of hounds, vintage cars, and horses and carriages returned.

The yearly event raises money for the preservation and maintenance of the garden and estate at Winterthur. It features steeple chase racing, pony races, raffles and more, but many come out for the tailgating and the opportunity to show off their fashions.

In terms of rites of spring, it's as Delaware as it gets.

Winterthur (5105 Kennett Pike, Winterthur) from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Sunday, May 7. For more details, visit winterthur.org or (302) 888-4600.

Running of the Bull, Dewey Beach

It’s a silly tradition for participants to get chased up the highway and onto Dewey Beach by a costumed bull. But this isn’t your average bull since it's powered by four human legs.

The Running of the Bull turns 26 this year and the event attracts thousands to The Starboard and Dewey Beach area with its festival atmosphere. The summer event offers a mix of the beach with a Mexican flavor. There will be sombreros, food on tap and lots of mischief.

Folks can donate $10 for the Rehoboth Beach Volunteer Fire Company.

The Starboard (2009 Coastal Highway, Dewey Beach). Date and times are TBD. For more info, visit therunningofthebull.com.

Delaware State Fair, Harrington

When it comes to entertainment in the First State, the 800-pound gorilla is the Delaware State Fair.

This was true even before Firefly decided to take a break this year. That’s because the State Fair is held over 10 days compared to Firefly’s four days.

Nonetheless, the fair will be extra important this year since Firefly is gone. But organizers already have wasted no time in bringing big-name acts to the M&T Bank Grandstand this summer.

Confirmed acts so far include the rapper Nelly, along with country acts Tyler Hubbard of Florida Georgia Line, plus Riley Green. The Demolition Derby also was announced.

Whether it’s the amusement rides, fried Oreos or the cuddly animals on display, there’s a little something for everyone at the State Fair.

Delaware State Fair (18500 S. Dupont Highway, Harrington) runs from Thursday, July 20 through Saturday, July 29. General admission tickets are up to $10 in person or $10.50 (online). Concerts on the Grandstand are extra. For more info, visit delawarestatefair.com or (302) 398-3269.

Burger Battle, Wilmington

It’s a real food fight whenever restaurants beef with each other in the tasty Burger Battle.

Last year’s event in August sold out, so you’ll want to get your tickets early for this 10th annual event.

The Burger Battle is the state’s premier food competition where chefs go head to head for bragging rights to the best burger in Delaware.

For one price, guests can go to each booth to sample a burger. But don’t be surprised if you fall short of completing that circuit.

Proceeds from the event benefit Delaware charities.

Rockford Park (Lookout Drive, Wilmington). Date and times haven’t been announced yet. For more info, visit deburgerbattle.com.

Delaware Renaissance Faire, Townsend

The Delaware Renaissance Faire is turning 2 this fall.

This toddler was born into a world of fantasy and intrigue that generated a huge buzz when it invaded Fire Base Lloyd in Townsend for a weekend last November.

This colorful festival from the days of yore featured performers who did everything from swallowing fire to sword fighting. There also was a diverse of group vendors.

Stay tuned for the announcement of the event’s fall dates and times. For more info, visit delafaire.com.

For updates on entertainment events throughout the year, sign up for DO Delaware, Andre Lamar's weekly entertainment newsletter.

More Delaware entertainment

Concerts in 2023:The return of Nelly, party for Swifties & more 2023 Delaware highlights

Delaware restaurants in 2023:Here are some you must try

'Clerks' legend Kevin Smith: He shows love to Wilmington actress starring in QVC holiday film

Delaware actor: He clowns around in new Tom Hanks film

Andre Lamar is the features/lifestyle reporter. If you have an interesting story idea, email Andre Lamar at alamar@gannett.com.

search_result.title: Crossroads: High School Report
search_result.text:
Schools are encourged to submit photographs to be posted online with High School Report and also in the print version of Crossroads when space allows. A submitted photograph should be a high resolution jpg and include a caption with people identified. Email to stringers@delawareonline.com.

Brandywine

Brandywine

Rising eighth-graders are invited to the Annual Transition Night! on March 27 when future Bulldogs can meet their teachers, coaches, club advisers, teammates and classmates. There will fun, games, door prizes and friendly faces.

Hunger doesn’t take a holiday — neither should food drives. The Key Club is collecting for the Claymont Community Food Closet with collection boxes located in the main office until Friday. Items needed include pancake mix, syrup, mac and cheese, oatmeal, peanut butter, jelly, tuna, soup, juice, canned fruit, green beans, peas and carrots, instant potatoes, pork and beans, beef ravioli, pasta and sauce.

Friday is the last day of the winter spirit week, and it is Brandywine Spirit Day. Students are encouraged to wear favorite Brandywine apparrel.

Emily Hyde

Mount Pleasant

An aluminum recycling event to benefit the band will be held Saturday. Hosted by the Band Boosters, it will be held in the school parking lot from 8 a.m. to noon. Residents of north Wilmington are asked to drop off cans, siding, ladders, door frames, window frames, scrap items, gas grill parts and any other aluminum-containing items to not only help fund band but to assist in environmental efforts.

The second Winter Concert will be held Tuesday evening.

The Prom Fashion Show is scheduled for 6:30 p.m. Feb. 28 in the auditorium.

This year’s musical “Hairspray” will be held March 27, 28 and 29.

Sydney Nye

Christina

Newark

In the 2014 PTA Reflections, the following students won for works pertaining to the national theme of “Believe, Dream, Inspire.” Those who placed first in their categories will compete in the state contest. In the Visual Arts category first place went to Jieun Kim,Brianna Quinones, Penelope Velasco and Carolina Velazquez; second place went to Amelia Way and Mekhi Pressey. In the dance category, first went to Steven Martinez and Julia Murphy. Dakota Edwards won first in photography.

Senior Andrew Milham signed his acceptance letter to Wilmington University Feb. 5. Milham

excelled in cross country, leading the Yellow Jackets boys team to second place in Division I.

Cole Bedford

Red Clay

Alexis I. du Pont

A.I. Dippers club adviser and science teacher Tami Soltow and about 80 students and teachers participated in the annual Polar Bear Plunge at Rehoboth Beach on Feb. 2. The club has raised about $6,800 for the Special Olympics so far this year, bringing its four-year total to more than $20,000. The club also will sponsor a dress down day on Feb. 21. The cost is $2 for students and $5 for teachers.

Smart Skills classes will be offered from 9 a.m. until 1 p.m. Feb. 22 and 23. Classes will be held at the student parking lot. To register visit: www.smartdrivede.org or call (888) 553-6543.

Communities in Schools will be collecting canned goods for National Canned Food Month during February and has begun a grief support group as of Feb. 6. Anyone who is interested in participating should see adviser Tamika Lee in Room 158.

The Wellness Center is up and running as of Feb. 3. Christiana Care staff is on-site and will be meeting with students to generate awareness. The process to get students enrolled and the services offered will be explained at a later date.

Cap and gown make-up orders were due by Monday. Seniors also should remember to pay senior dues in guidance. Senior T-shirt day for class of 2014 is today. Shirts are for sale for $10 in guidance.

Charter

Senior Julia Johansson was the monthly Jefferson Award recipient for January. She initially founded a chapter within Charter for the Dreamcatchers Foundation, a nonprofit organization which aims to grant wishes to terminally ill patients, and expanded it into an East Coast branch after attending a leadership conference in Washington. Julia now continues to provide club support at the St. Francis Hospital by helping to arrange dinners, collect gifts and plan day trips for the residents of the hospital.

The Jefferson Council held its Winter Ball Masquerade recently at the Delaware Children’s Museum on theWilmington Riverfront. All proceeds benefited the museum.

The B+ Charterthon culminates on Feb. 22.Students are raising money and support for childhood cancer research.

Multiple students were awarded with a Michael C. Ferguson Scholarship for their high DCAS scores in reading and mathematics with 34 of the 284 recipients. Each received a $1,000 scholarship for his or her respective reading or mathematics score. Recipients included Eshan Agarwal, William Barndt, Duncan Bower, Nicolette Bugher, Joseph Buxton, Andrew Constantine, Olivia DiMaio, Savarn Dontamsetti, Emma Herdman, Benjamin Hoeschel, Grace Kim, Irene Luo, Derek Mann, Surena Modarres Moosavy, Hannah Ni, Austin Pennington,Vickram Rajendran, Mark Redman, Henry Rogatz, Victor Rojas, Jared Siskin, Sarah Snyder, Christina Stiebris, Lucy Sullivan, Rohith Venkataraman, Rebecca Wadman, Jasmine Wang, Jessica Wang, Miles Wang, Richard Wang, David Xu, Emily Yan, George Yang and Jeffrey Zhao.

Senior Kyle Plusch is the state winner in Wendy’s High School Heisman program for his excellent golf record. Since its founding in 1994, this prestigious program has honored more than 395,000 skilled high school seniors in partnership with the Heisman Memorial Trophy Committee. The honorees are well-rounded students who excel in all academic areas, both on and off of the field.

Monica Keszler

Conrad

The Blue-Gold Club and Best Buddies will sell Pledge Respect T-shirts for Special Olympics Delaware and will participate in Spread the Word to End the Word Day in March. Shirts are $5 and are on sale until Feb. 19.

Twenty-six Conrad and A.I. du Pont advanced placement human-geography students competed in World Quest, an academic bowl on Feb. 1. This is the second year competing for both schools.

The Business Professionals of America club is gearing up for the state competition on Feb. 26 at the Rollins Center at Dover Downs Hotel and Casino. The competition will highlight student leadership, networking and business acumen.

The Blue-Gold Club held a fundraiser at Buffalo Wild Wings on Feb. 5. The fundraiser supports the Delaware Foundation Reaching Citizens with intellectual disabilities.

Alexia Scott

Delaware Military

Currently, 279 of the academy’s families (54 percent) have participated in the DMA fundraiser. It is important all families participate.

Shining Seahawks for January are freshman Johnny Means, nominated by Mr. O’Kneski; sophomore Chloe McBride, nominated by Ms. Carson; junior David Carey, nominated by Mr. Austin, and senior Joseph Holden, nominated by Ms. Rogers.

The auction will be held March 14 and families are encouraged to donate items or their services (electricians, handymen or women, plumbers, etc.). To donate, volunteer or for more information, contact Annette D’Angelo at mooge@aol.com

Cadets Joseph Holden and Christiana Taylor were selected for All-State Music Ensembles. Holden will be in All-State Senior Mixed Choir for the third consecutive year. The All-State Choir concert will be at Seaford High School at 7 p.m. Feb. 22. Taylor will perform with the All-State Senior Band at 6 p.m. April 5 at Smyrna High School It is her third year, also.

Brittany Carson

Dickinson

Three students were recognized for excellence in the 2013 Delaware Comprehensive Assessment System tests. The winners of the Michael C. Ferguson $1,000 scholarships were Sarah Gotthold (eighth-grade reading), Emily Ragan (10th-grade mathematics) and Dylan Ridge (10th-grade reading).

Jobs for Delaware Graduates adviser Dionie Lum and four students visited the Dover Air Force Base Friday for a tour of the base. They also had the opportunity to take in a presentation on leadership. Attending were Michael Geldof, Malik Harper, Daniel Jones and Carlshay Williams.

Friday is an in-service day for teachers. Students are off from school. They also are off Monday in observance of Presidents Day.

McKean

McKean will hold its first Mardi Gras themed dance for students on Feb. 22. Ticket sales, at $10, are underway. It is hoped the dance will become an annual event with a sense of Bourbon Street.

Hours are 7:30 and 10:30 and there will be food and special New Orleans slushies.

Today’s theme on The WMHS music party is “Love.” Tune in at 2:30 p.m. on WMHS-FM (88.1).

Moises Velazquez

Charter

Delaware Academy

Tac-Ops cadets again have given back to the community. On Feb. 1,14 cadets attended and assisted in the 5k. On Feb. 2, 20 cadets assisted in the Polar Bear Plunge at Rehoboth Beach, a charity event that raises money for Special Olympics. This year, the Polar Bear Plunge earned $725,000. In addition to the money, seven cadets took the plunge: Ed Dimauro, Shawn Pedicone, Vince Sargeni, Karina Perez, Cory Spade, Jaclyn Swanson and JC Wissler.

The Math League tasted sweet victory. when the team came in third place against Howard, Conrad, Tall Oaks and Delaware Military Academy. The team was led by ninth-grader Shaina Copeland and

rookie Kyle Lang, who led the team by two points. Special acknowledgment goes to Raekwon Brickhouse, Shubham Patel, Steven Pierson, Raquel Silva and Jaclyn Swanson.

On Feb. 22, Delaware Academy Public Safety and Security will hold its first Winterfest from 7 to 11 p.m. at 801 N. du Pont Highway, New Castle. It is for adults 21 and older. One ticket, which includes beer/wine, buffet, music and dancing, costs $30. Silent auctions and raffles also will be available. All earnings will benefit the academy. For more information, contact erin.leighty@dapss.k12.de.us or pam.trakas@dapss.k12.de.us or call (302) 322-6050.

Gloria Bernal and

Jeilsia Jimenez

Newark Charter

On Feb. 4, the school store opened its doors to junior/senior high school students for the first time. Business teacher Christine Orzechowski, along with select students, will operate the store before and after school. Students can buy snacks, extra supplies and spirit wear.

Some 31 members of the Adventure Club traveled to Bear Creek Mountain to enjoy snowboarding, skiing and tubing.

Marine Science Club members participated in the Chesapeake Bay Bowl and the Regional National Ocean Sciences Bowl competition on Feb. 1 in Lewes. The team included Samantha Robers, Jason Dryer, Marian Spencer, Charmy Patel and competitors Olivia Stritzinger, Hannah Cooper, Addie Morgado, Ashley Logue and Lindsey Feldmann.

Nora Pickering was selected as the Newark Charter School Voice of February.

Luci Ostheimer

Private

Archmere

Seniors Shing Shing Cao, Jonathan Lobo, Michael Bannon and Rebecca Peet were named candidates for the U.S. Presidential Scholars Program.

On Feb. 4, Father Domenic Rossi, founder and executive director of Bethesda Project, talked to students about his life and service as a member of the Norbertines as well as to discuss the Bethesda Project, a nonprofit organization that operates 14 shelter, transitional and permanent supportive housing sites throughout Philadelphia. To learn more about the project and how you can help, go to www.bethesdaproject.org or like the Bethesda Project Facebook page.

Scholastic Art Awards recently were awarded. Eight students received Gold Key awards for individual works and 13 received silver key awards for individual works. Among the individual winners was a Gold Key for sophomore John Vaile’s sculpture, “The Animal Within.” John was also nominated for the American Vision Award. He is one of five students who have been considered for this award in the region. The Silver and Gold recipients’ works were displayed in the Delaware State University gallery in Dover.

Students recognized for their portfolios were senior Alexandra Cassidy who received a Gold Key for photography; senior Olivia Arasim, Silver Key, photography; senior Jonathan Gazzillo, Silver Key, photography; senior Conor Wilkinson, Silver Key, photography; senior Cierrah Doran, Honorable Mention, digital art; senior Kelcey Hutchinson, Honorable Mention, art; senior Cara Nedbalski, Honorable Mention, photography, and senior Luke Spoehr, Honorable Mention, art.

Individual works recognized were: Gold Key: senior Sarah Donnelly, senior Cierrah Doran, senior Kelcey Hutchinson, sophomore Claire Mooseberg, sophomore Joseph Singley, senior Alexa Spence, freshman Brooke Ulmanis and sophomore John Vaile. Silver Key: senior Noah Anderson, sophomore Sophia Cipriano, junior Kurt Clements, sophomore Lilly Coogan, sophomore Connor Dennewitz, senior Kelcey Hutchinson, senior Laura Jogani, junior Maggie Maurer, sophomore Claire Mooseberg, frehman Alexandra Reilly, senior Asunta Rossi, sophomore Joseph Singley andsenior Luke Spoehr. Honorable Mentions: senior Noah Anderson, freshman Max Beck, junior Ashley Burns, sophomore Sophia Cipriano, senior Kenny D’Aurizio, junior Thomas Diamanty, senior Cierrah Doran, freshman Emma Hogan, senior Kelcey Hutchinson, freshman Haley Levinsky, senior Jonathan Lobo, junior Kelley Lucey, senior Maryanna Lynch, freshman Sanjana Malik, junior Katie Maurer, junior Lauren McBride, sophomore Philip Miller, senior Haley Moore, sophomore Claire Moosberg, junior Justine Pantaleo, junior Joseph Singley, senior Katelyn Singley and senior Luke Spoehr.

Jordan Aulen

Fairwinds Christian

The National Christian Honor Society Induction was held Wednesday. Details on the induction will be posted in a future report.

There were many basketball games last week, including a Feb. 4 away varsity game against Salem. There were home games against Calvary on Feb. 6.

The Science Fair/ Open house will be held Feb. 28. Contact the office for more information about attending.

People can follow the school on Instgram @FCSKnights to keep up to date with activities. People also like the Fairwinds Christian School Facebook page.

Kara Gallaher

Padua

Brother Michael Rosenello was honored during Brother Mike Day at Fournier Hall on Feb. 1. He was recognized for his many years of contributions to St. Anthony’s basketball. The day involved basketball games, a skills contest and a dedication of Fournier Hall’s new floor. Mass was celebrated and a reception held.

Members of the X Squared Factor Robotics team competed in the Delaware First State Qualifier on Feb. 1. The team finished ninth overall.

More than 40 students from Padua and Salesianum plunged into the Atlantic Ocean to benefit the Special Olympics at the Feb. 2 Polar Bear Plunge. Salesianum raised more than $800 and Padua raised more than $3,200.

The “Once Upon a Mattress” musical will be held Friday through Sunday. Tickets cost $8 and may be purchased at the door.

On Sunday, the Delaware Coalition Against Domestic Violence will hold a bowling event from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m.Students are encouraged to attend to support women. The Students In Action Team will attend.

There will be no school Monday as it is Presidents Day.

The India Pakistan Project will be held Wednesday. Students are encouraged to attend to learn more about the history, cultures and relationship between India and Pakistan.

Parent-Student-Teacher conferences will be held 3 to 7 p.m. Feb. 20.

Individuals from Kennett Design will visit Feb. 26. This day will be held exclusively for those learning how to create a version of Van Gogh’s “Starry Night.” The event also will include house-made crepes by the French teachers.

Nikki Rash

Salesianum

The Feast Day Prayer Service on Jan. 21 celebrated the life of the school’s patron saint, St. Francis de Sales and the life of Martin Luther King Jr. The schoolwide prayer service was organized by the Minority Coalition and the Student Council to remind faculty and students of the importance of diversity. Juniors Miguel Tapia and Jonathan Mendez spoke of the link between St. Francis’ message that differences should be celebrated and King’s vision for equality. Students from the Minority Coalition and Student Council took turns reading portions of King’s “I Have a Dream” speech.

Salesianum will roll out a new STEM course for students next school year with Introduction to engineering - new product development. The course will use the same textbook as the introductory

engineering course at the University of Delaware and will incorporate aspects of robotics with a foundation in robotics and programming. Students will have an opportunity to create a business proposal and work with teams on a project of their choice while building working prototypes, testing their designs and filing provisional patents. The course will conclude with an engineering fair and a “Shark Tank”-style presentation. The course will be taught by Creighton Anderson, who has a master’s degree in engineering and worked in new product development as an engineer prior to teaching.

Stephen Ryan

Sanford

Senior Amira Hannon is a finalist for a 2014 Achievement Scholarship by The National Achievement Scholarship Program. Worth more than $2.5 million, approximately 800 awards will be given to students in the spring.

Both the upper and middle schools 2013 literary magazines were recognized for their outstanding merit by the National Council of Teachers of English. Inscape, the upper school magazine, earned a rating of “Superior” and can be viewed online at sanfordnewsnetwork.com. Sanford was the only school in Delaware to receive this high honor. Meta4, the middle school magazine, earned a rating of “Excellent.” Sanford was the only middle school in Delaware to receive this honor. The student editors for both magazines include seniors Breanna Light and Courtney Clark and freshmen Caroline Cook, Emily Boyer, Jackie Bracho and Fiona Jicha.

Seventh-grader William Zimmer recently won the Middle School Geography Bee.

Prior to winter break, the middle school held a Penny Wars competition to raise money for the Leukemia Lymphoma Society. The Student Council recently presented a check to representatives from the LLS after the middle school students raised more than $2,500.

Christopher Malafronti

St. Elizabeth

Senior Marissa Janicki was a winner in the statewide Scholastic Writing Awards Competition. She was awarded a Silver Key for her poem “Daydream Debris.” The other submitted poems and prose writings in her Senior Portfolio entry received Honorable Mention. Winners received their awards at a reception and exhibition of winning works at Delaware State University in Dover Saturday.

Senior Leigh Bernetich was the January recipient of a Jefferson Award in recognition of several hundreds of service hours contributed during her high school years. A few of her service projects include assisting her elderly neighbors with difficult tasks, participating in charity walks and fundraiser, and managing the St. E varsity baseball team.

Michael Bennett, spokesman for the Jefferson Awards Youth Service Group at St. E, said “This Viking has gone above and beyond the MANNA requirement to embody our Benedictine tradition of selfless service. Even with a strenuous course load that includes [advanced placement] classes and participation in various academic clubs, this senior finds the time to volunteer within her school, her parish, and beyond.”

Monday is a school holiday in honor of Presidents Day.

The Delaware Lahore Delhi Partnership for Peace will meet Wednesday at Padua Academy to hear Deputy Chief of Mission of the Embassy of India Taranjit Singh Sandhu. Ambassador Sandhu assumed his current assignment in Washington in July 2013. Prior to that, he was consul general of India in Frankfurt, Germany, and served in the Ministry of External Affairs as joint secretary (United Nations) and later as joint secretary (administration) heading the Human Resource Department Division. The Pakistan Project is a partnership between the Delaware Lahore Delhi Partnership for Peace and the Lahore Mozang Rotary Club, aimed at bridging the cultural divide between the United States and Pakistan. The project’s educational series introduces junior and senior high school students to the issues of world peace, politics and diplomacy.

Vincent DiLissio

St. Mark’s

Senior swimmer Maggie Slocomb was named The News Journal’s Athlete of the Week for her recent performance against Archmere. Coach Rob Maegerle said, “She’s phenomenal ... She has all four strokes. She really does not have a weakness.”

Senior Patrick McVay recently won highest honors in the second meet of this year’s WordWright challenge, a national competition for high school students requiring close reading and analysis of many different kinds of prose and poetry. McVay earned a near-perfect score and placed among the 99 highest-scoring 12th-graders in the nation. Adviser is Anne Eanes.

Senior Amanda Joyce was featured in a WDEL segment recently for her role in training service dogs. Dyson and Frolic, golden retrievers, are puppies with which Joyce is working to be a service dog. Joyce has had one of the dogs with her in school every day this year and is currently working with Dyson. Joyce was inspired by her sister, Alex, class of 2010, who requires help from her service dog, Dee Dee, as a result of a degenerative neurological disease. Alex spent two years at St. Mark’s with Dee Dee, who was an honorary graduate of the school as a tribute to her service. Joyce’s segment is online at the St. Mark’s website and will be aired again this Saturday.

Junior Ryan Minnehan recently earned her certification as a Level I USA archery instructor. Not only was Minnehan the only female in her certification group, she was also the youngest by many years at the age of 16. Minnehan, who is a member of the New Castle 100 Archers archery club, also competes in the Junior Olympic Archery Division.

Parent College Information Night will be held in the cafeteria on from 7 to 9 p.m. Wednesday. Important details of the college application process will be discussed. This night is geared for juniors and their parents, but underclassmen and their parents are welcome to attend. Contact Wayne Smeigh or Yvette Drazich in college placement for more information.

Registration for the class of 2018 will be held from 7 to 9 p.m. Feb. 20. Parents of admitted students intending to enroll freshmen for the 2014-2015 school year are invited to attend registration. Administrators will discuss the general academic program and course progression for freshmen. Parents can ask general questions of faculty and administrators. For more information, contact Matthew Evans, director of admissions, at 757-8723.

The Parent Association’s fourth annual Wine and Beer Tasting from 7 to 10 p.m. Feb. 22 in the cafeteria. Cost is $10 in advance and $15 at the door and can be purchased online. Parents of incoming freshmen are invited to be our guest and are asked to contact Francis Corrigan, executive director of Mission and Ministry, at fcorrigan@stmarkshs.net or Tricia Curtin White at pcurtin@christianacare.org. Tickets will be held at the door

The Spartan Athletic Club Concert and Auction will be March 29. Listen to the sounds of Blue Label, led by former Burnt Sienna frontman Jefe while supporting the athletic program. Contact S.A.C. committee members Brian Murray at btmurray@btmurray.net or Michele Mirabella at mirabella22@verizon.net for information.

To reserve a Spartan for a Day visit call Shustine Brooks in the admissions office at 757-8721 at least one week in advance.

Jake Bertelson

Tatnall

On Feb. 5, four Tatnall seniors officially committed to be college student-athletes at Pennsylvania State University, Yale University, Lehigh University and North Carolina State University. Shay Cannon will play field hockey for Penn State, Jennifer Davis will play squash for Yale, Jack Hagood will run cross country/track and field for North Carolina State and Henry Paul will run cross country/track and field for Lehigh.

The Annual Gala & Silent Auction runs from 7 to 11 p.m. March 1. Previously known as the “Party for a Purpose,” this event allows the Tatnall parent community to come together to celebrate the school.

While many are eagerly awaiting warmer weather, the preschool and lower school students have been taking advantage of the cold weather by sledding during recess. Tatnall’s 110-acre campus provides the perfect winter wonderland for releasing extra energy during cold winter days.

The Eighth-Grade Parent Night is scheduled for Tuesday in the Beekley student lounge starting at 7 p.m. There will be information about life in the Upper School, including details about the daily and weekly schedule, various academic course options, graduation requirements and how best to prepare for the college process.

Tatnall hosted Dr. Leslie Conner and Dr. Cate McCarthy on Monday for a presentation on parenting through the teen years, “The Tug of War of the Teen Years: Parenting for Adulthood.” The presentation covered adolescent development and how to stay connected as you let go.

Feb. 20 marks opening night for the 50th anniversary of Showcase. This year’s upper school students, instructed by Bruce Chipman, who has taught the class for 41 years, are performing “The Curious Savage.” Showtimes are 7:30 p.m. Feb. 20-22 at the Laird Performing Arts Center. Tickets will be sold at the door.

Tower Hill

Casino night, organized by the Green and White club, raised more than $15,000 for the athletic program. The club appreciates the efforts of sponsors, people who donated raffle items and those who put in time and work to make the night a success.

Author and illustrator Matt Phelan will visit lower and middle school students on March 12. He will present assemblies to the students, work with the seventh grade in their English classes and have lunch with several sixth-grade reading students. Among the children’s books Phelan has illustrated are “Very Hairy Bear” and “Flora’s Very Windy Day.” He also has written graphic novels for older children including “Bluffton” and a Scott O’Donnell historical fiction award winner, “The Storm in the Barn.” Phelan will autograph books, which can be pre-ordered in The Weathervane. The order deadline is Friday.

The middle school continued a 10-year tradition of adopting a highway. The tradition was started by former alumni and English teacher John Pierson. After participating in the Hiller Heats community breakfast on Martin Luther King Jr. Day, middle-school students and teachers headed out to their adopted highway, a small stretch of Del. 82, to clean the area.

The first Hiller Hearts event was a success. Through much work from the many people who organized the event and the 200 families who came together, more than $1,800 was raised for Darkness to Light organization and numerous items were collected to be donated to the Department of Family Services and Child Inc. Much thanks to all who contributed and made the day a success. The Hiller Hearts event laid the foundation for a schoolwide commitment to service and charitable efforts on behalf of children everywhere.

Spencer Johnson

Ursuline

On Jan. 26, the Mass of Celebration thanked the Ursuline sisters for 120 years of dedicated service to more than 4,800 alumnae and for providing the foundation for lay leaders to continue educating students in the spirit of St. Angela Merici.

On Jan. 27, the community came together to celebrate the Feast of St. Angela at a Mass presided over by Bishop Malooly. Later in the day, to kick off Catholic Schools Week, upper school students held a talent show and awarded the Teacher Emmys, and the class of 2014 performed Senior Skits. Throughout the week, students enjoyed a variety of theme days and activities, including Teacher Appreciation Day, Pajama Day and Color Wars.

On Feb. 2, 32 students participated in the Polar Bear Plunge at Rehoboth Beach. The Frosty Raiders team raised more than $2,700 to benefit the Special Olympics.

On Feb. 5, seniors Laura Hurff and Kennedy Wong made their official collegiate athletic commitments among family, friends and members of the Athletic Department. Hurff signed a National Letter of Intent with Syracuse University to play field hockey and Wong signed an Athletic Commitment, stating she would join the team when she attends in the fall, to run cross country/track at the University of Pennsylvania.

Senior Emma Field recently was named to the 2013-2014 Delaware All-State Band. This prestigious ensemble of instrumentalists is comprised of hundreds of applicants from throughout the state, and this is Emma’s fifth year of earning this honor for the flute.

Elizabeth Coniglio

Wilmington Christian

The 10th-12th grade Math League won first place in the last meet of the season on Jan. 28, defeating Dickinson, A.I. du Pont, St. Elizabeth and Sanford (currently ranked No. 1 in the region). The team was lead by seniors Michael Gray, Austin Hahn, Corbin McNeill, Aaron Miller and Yi Zhao. The final meet, to determine the regional champion, was held Feb 4. at Wilmington Christian School. Results will be announced in a future report.

Faculty member Stephanie Barrick was pleased with the awards received by her high school art students at the annual state Scholastic Art Awards. Artists who received a Gold Key or Silver Key had their winning pieces on display through Saturday in the Arts Center Gallery of Delaware State University in Dover. The closing reception and awards ceremony for the Gold Key winners took place that morning.

Maddy Deaton (design), May Lu (printmaking), Mikaylah Perry (fashion design) and Leah Ro (drawing) received Gold Keys. Isaac Barrick (drawing), Leah Ro (painting) and William Zhong (photography) received Silver Keys. Honorable Mentions went to Leah Ro (received four awards), Cassie Otersen (two awards), Katie Barton, Hanna Alderman, Sydney Baffone, Isaac Barrick, Maddy Deaton, Jenny Kurlej, James Rath and William Zhong. Silver Key and Honorable Mention awards will be presented at the WCS Spring Awards Assembly.

Seniors Katherine Arnold, Kelly McGrail and Zosia Roberts were selected to the 2013 Gladiator by SGI / NFHCA High School National Academic Squad. The High School National Academic Squad program recognizes high school seniors who have achieved a minimum cumulative, unweighted GPA of 3.5 through the first quarter of the 2013-14 school year. Arnold also was designated as a Scholar of Distinction, for achieving an unweighted GPA of 3.9 or higher.

Spirit Week awards were given out in a special assembly on Feb. 4. The judging categories were: class poster, homeroom door design, class participation and class skits. The juniors took first place, with the sophomores in second place, the senior class taking third and the freshmen finishing fourth.

Feb. 4 also was an Open House day, with many new families visiting the campus. The next Open House day will be 9 to 11 a.m. March 4.

A.J. Stiles

Wilmington Friends

The “rookie” upper school Robotics team made a splash at the Delaware Region’s FIRST Championship, competing against 27 teams. The “Bad News Bots” won five of six matches, the second highest total score for any Delaware team, qualifying for the semi-finals. Faculty advisers are physics teacher Matt Cauchy and computer science teacher Jenks Whittenburg. The team includes seniors Chase Conley, Matt Schmittle, Dan Shaw and Joey Woodward; juniors Jimmy Carney, Jacob Gagliano, and Spencer Hall; sophomores Jack Bulk, Michael Ly, and Drew Pittenger; and freshmen Hannah Kushner, Andrew Slomski, Margaret Sullivan and Chris Wallace.

Head of Upper School Rebecca Zug will host a coffee for parents this morning. The focus is on course selections for next year, so parents of students in grade nine through 11 may find it beneficial. There will be another event for current eighth-grader parents to talk about ninth-grade scheduling and course selections.

Mid-winter break, with no classes, is Friday through Monday. There is no child care. Upper school coaches will set practice schedules for each team.

The Quaker Closet quality re-sale shop will be open to the public 8:15 a.m. to 4 p.m. Tuesday, a rescheduled date, because of snow closing, for February donations and consignments. Starting in February, the Quaker Closet requests only spring items as donations, please. The “QC” has a separate entrance with a doorbell, toward the parking lot side of the middle/upper school building.

The IB visual arts, visual arts major, 3-D design and French IV and V classes will take a field trip to Washington Wednesday.

Also on Wednesday, Head of Lower School Annette Hearing and Lower School librarian and media technology teacher Kate McCarron will hold a coffee for lower school parents interested in learning more about Internet safety.

Wednesday is the next scheduled session in the India-Pakistan educational series sponsored by the Lahore-Delhi Partnership for Peace. This event will feature the Jhankaar Bollywood Dance Troupe, led by creative director, choreographer and dancer Nisha Punjabi. The group specializes in presentations in semi-classical forms, folk dance, and contemporary Bollywood style, with a focus on cultural preservation and forms for dancers and audiences of all backgrounds.

Finally on Wednesday, parents have been invited to participate in an evening discussion as part of the school’s reaccreditation and planning processes. Contact Assistant Head of School for academics Peter Wenigmann with questions.

Julia Rhodes

Maryland

Tome

The National Honor Society will hold a bake sale Feb. 20 to raise funds for Alex’s Lemonade Stand to support cancer reseaerch. Baked goods like cookies and brownies, and of course, lemonade, will be sold to the high school during lunch.

As well, students are collecting for Sundi’s Gift, which asks for new and gently used shoe donations, the proceeds of which support the construction of water wells in Africa. Boxes will be placed around the school until Feb. 21 to collect shoes.

Recently, seniors Christian Cholish and Lauren Llewellyn designed, organized and held Heritage Day, a festival celebrating diversity and heritage for the lower school. In the morning, junior Madison Benner performed a Scottish swords dance and senior Kyra Adanalian sang an Armenian hymn. Alumnus Bryson Kemp wowed with various instruments from across the world, while Sean Mulligan of Rising Sun, Md., played both traditional and original Irish compositions on the viola. Afterward, students in grades one through four participated in stories and crafts, and finally, were served a potluck prepared by members of the National Honor Society.

Christian Cholish

and Leah Llewellyn

search_result.text:
WIL

Schools are encourged to submit photographs to be posted online with High School Report and also in the print version of Crossroads when space allows. A submitted photograph should be a high resolution jpg and include a caption with people identified. Email to stringers@delawareonline.com.

Brandywine

Brandywine

Another Spirit Week starts Monday. Monday is Pajama Day, Tuesday Twin Day, Wednesday Tie Dye Day, Feb. 13 BHS Spirit Day, Feb. 14 Class Colors Day. Hallway decorating will take place Feb. 13 after school; all students should contact class officers on how to help.

The Class of 2014 is collaborating with Aeropostale and DoSomething.org in a service project called Jeans For Teens. The effort, lead by senior Joel Hurtt, addresses the fact that one in three people who are homeless are younger than 18 years old, and jeans are the most requested item by them. Any old or unworn jeans should be brought to the school by Feb. 14 and placed in the designated box located in the main office. The goal is 1,000 jeans.

Emily Hyde

Concord

Midterms concluded starting the first week of the second semester last week. Students began to adjust to new schedules and meet new teachers. The first-semester report-card grades and midterms were distributed last week. The first semester grades also were sent to the colleges the seniors applied to automatically by the school.

A Confident Parenting workshop was held at Claymont Elementary School. This seminar was to help struggling parents to become more adjusted into their roles.

The annual Polar Bear Plunge was held Sunday at Rehoboth Beach to raise funds for the Special Olympics Delaware. For the third year in a row, the Concord Cannonballs participated. The team was led by seniors Rhiannon Downey and Alex Gendrachi, under the supervision of the Blue-Gold adviser Donna Ames.

Wednesday, a police presentation on senior week was offered to parents and students. The police answered questions and left the students and parents more informed of the rules and regulations concerning those participants of beach week.

Mount Pleasant

The Michael C. Ferguson Achievement Awards, granted to those few students receiving the most outstanding scores in DCAS testing, were given to eight Mount Pleasant students for their exceptional performance last year as sophomores. They included: Emma Chambless, Lydia Christman, Alexis Ellison, John Kee, Kali Panella, Jordan Siskin, David Unterberger and Rebecca Williams.

Blue-Gold senior ambassadors Molly Kerrigan and Annie Garner and junior ambassadors Abby Betts and Melinda Bilous attended a leadership training session for the Blue-Gold Game on June 21.

Another winter concert will be held on the evening of Feb. 18.

The Prom Fashion Show will be held Feb. 28 in the auditorium.

The annual musical has been announced and casted; director Chris Turner and the school will present "Hairspray" on March 27, 28 and 29.

The National Honor Society soon will begin its "Pennies for Patients" fundraiser for leukemia, and the period A class collecting the most change will be served a complimentary breakfast.

Sydney Nye

Colonial

William Penn

The Young Playwrights hosts a competition in which students can submit their own original five to 10 page plays and have them published and performed. The Delaware division of the program is sponsored by the Delaware Theater Company. This year's competition started in September; winning plays will be performed in March. Student Samantha Stewart's play "To Break the Ice" was one of the four selected from the Delaware to be performed. "I've always loved to write and act, so I really enjoyed this," said Samantha.

This year's theme was "A small detail making a big difference."

"I got the idea for my play from a pick-up line I heard," said Samantha. "It was, 'how much does a polar bear weigh? Enough to break the ice' ... I got the idea for the main character to use it and begin talking to the other main character, and that's where it starts."

The Delaware Theatre Company will present the winning plays later this year.

More information is available on The Delaware Theatre Company website.

Jessica Paoletti

and Aeon Scott

Red Clay

Alexis I. du Pont

Tami Soltow, science and legal processes teacher, recently was selected to receive the 2014 Award for Excellence as a Classroom LRE Teacher by the Delaware Law Related Education Center.

The school will hold an open house at the Latin American Community Center on from 6 to 7 p.m. Feb. 18. Uniforms will be on display along with information about various programs.

The Nature and Garden Club has received various "plaque level" donations toward its "Walkway to Success" brick fund. Sponsors so far include the "Hoe 'n Hope Garden Club," which has donated more than $1,000, former A.I. chemistry teacher Barb Borleski and former A.I. biology teacher Eddie McGrath.

Austin Griffith

Charter

Student Hannah Cho has been named concertmaster of the Delaware Honors Orchestra Festival, the new Delaware All-State Orchestra. She was also ranked No. 1 in the top 10 overall scores.

Freshman Caden Anderson recently completed his Eagle Scout project. He and fellow students Eamon and Patrick O'Conner, Spencer Harmon, Michael Lan and other local musicians provided a concert for families at the Ronald McDonald House. In addition, he also collected more than 100 pounds of food, cleaning supplies and new toys for the house.

Monica Keszler has been awarded with the 2014 Scholastics Gold Key Portfolio Award for her senior portfolio. She is the only one from Charter this year to receive the award, and one of two from the Cab Calloway AP Studio Art class. Her work in full, all eight submitted pieces, will be on display at Delaware State University in Dover on Feb. 8. Other Scholastics Art Awards from Charter include Individual Gold Key and Silver Key Portfolio winner Christine Fu, Individual Silver Key winners Seoyeon Kim, Julia Lin and Ginda Sun and Honorable Mention Portfolio Isabelle Elkins. All Gold Key works will be submitted for national adjudication later this year.

Ben Fickles, Asher Feldman and Hannah Beiner were recipients of the 2014 Scholastic Writing Award. C

The HUG Club has started its Second Annual Prom Dress Drop collection. All donated dresses will be sold for $10 and all proceeds will be donated to IFOPA, an organization dedicated to researching for the cure for Fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva, a rare muscle disease in which damaged connective tissue fails to grow.

Following in the spirit of giving back, the Bollywood Dance Club recently held a World's Fair dance show at Brandywine Springs Elementary School. Dance groups performed dances from countries around the world, and varying cuisine from foreign nations was provided. All proceeds went to Kolkata Sanved, a charity which removes children from human trafficking circles, and instead teaches them dance as a form of therapy.

Tobias Mazal

Conrad

The state Department of Education is running a fundraiser for HOSA Future Health Professionals. The money raised is to help fund National Conference travel for the five students who are state officers. JulietteEmery is one of them. Please consider purchasing some jewelry from the online catalog.

About 1,000 plus interviews of potential students have been conduced by the school so far this year. Choice applications closed Jan. 8. Almost 1,500 students applied this year.

TravisTesta was chosen as Conrad's player representative for the Blue-Gold All-Star football game in June. LizGraham will represent Conrad on the Blue Team cheerleading squad.

Freshman Katrina Hardy placed second in Delaware in the Disability History and Awareness Month Poster Contest from the Governor's Advisory Council for Exceptional Citizens. Katrina represented Conrad at an awards luncheon in Dover with Lt. Gov. MattDenn.

David and BryceFender have earned Eagle Scout rank, the highest in Boy Scouting. David is a recent graduate and Bryce is a junior. Both young men have earned six other previous ranks having to do with aspects of camping, life, cooking and survival skills. Only two out of 100 people who join the Boy Scouts achieve this level.

Alexia Scott

Delaware Military

The start of the third marking period began Monday. If the first two haven't gone as planned, now is the time to make the necessary changes.

Letters of acceptance have been sent to the incoming 2014-15 freshman class. We are looking forward to having these young men and women become part of the DMA family.

Monday was Community Service Day. Many cadets and staff attended the Polor Bear Plunge in Rehoboth Beach on Sunday.

The wrestling team went 2-1 in a quad meet two weekends ago. They defeated Caravel and Lake Forest. The boys varsity and JV basketball teams defeated McKean two weeks ago, as well. The varsity boys team improved to 8-4 on the season. The girls basketball team also defeated McKean to improve to 7-4 on the season. The boys swim team defeated both Archmere and Sanford. The girls swim team got its first win of the season against Sanford, as well.

Brittany Carson

Dickinson

Jobs for Delaware Graduates held its officer induction ceremony on Jan. 21. The ceremony, conducted by adviser Dionie Lum, recognized Randi Hocker (president), Terri Harden (vice-president), Daniel DiPilla (secretary), Xavier Deleon (treasurer), Jaylon Dickerson (co-historian) and Carlshay Williams (co-historian).

Junior Seth Schilling was published in the January issue of Teen Ink magazine. Schilling wrote a poem, "Masque."

The February Dickinson Support Association meeting will take place at 7 p.m. Tuesday in the library.

The February Coffee Series will take place from 8 to 9 a.m. Wednesday. Interested parents of prospective students can see the school during a typical day. Contact the main office at 992-5500, ext. 301, to reserve a spot. Coffee will be served.

McKean

Do you, your relatives, or friends have have a 3- to 4-year-old child who is ready for more than your mom's playgroup? If you do, please consider enrolling them in the McKean's Lil Highlanders, a four-day play group styled preschool designed to provide children with activities to promote social and educational development. The morning session runs from 9:15 to 10:45 Mondays through Thursdays. Cost is $50 a month.

The staff is McKean high school students who have demonstrated excellence. They will be supervised by a qualified early childhood educator. For more information, contact director Lisa Gonzon at 992-1949

Today's theme on The WMHS music party will be "Forgive and Forget." at 2:30 p.m. on WMHS-FM (88.1).

Moises Velazquez

Charter

Newark Charter

On Jan. 28, ninth-graders from the global studies class traveled to Washington with teacher Lisa Westerfield for a seminar organized by the Genocide Awareness Organization from the Enough Project. They included Megan McCormick, Selena Juarez, Elaine Ansah, Paige Feldman, Aashna Kohtari, Luci Ostheimer, Patrick Carmen, Brianna Johnson, Annie Greene and Cece Moore. They discussed Sudan and what they can do to help the schools in Darfur refugee camps, including receiving a Darfuri sister school. They also went to the House of Representatives to seek support for a bill allowing the United States to send aid to the refugees in Darfur.

In other news, the Mock Trial team is preparing for its competition Feb. 21-22 at the New Castle County Courthouse.

The eighth-grade Math League Team placed first and second in the Jan. 28 Regional Competition. The team was led by top scorers Michael Chen and Christina Kim.

The seventh-grade Math League Team won first, second and third place in the Regional Competition. Joannie Wang and Mathias Heider led the school with top scores. After three meets, Joannie currently leads all seventh-graders in the region.

Luci Ostheimer

Private

Archmere

An app imagined by a team of Archmere students won "Best in State" in the Verizon Innovative App Challenge. Led by computer science teacher Jared Campbell, students Christian Kraft, Gregory McCord, Joseph Spall, Andrew Hurst and Nicholas McIntyre developed the concept for a mobile application they call "coNextGen," which helps individuals locate family members and friends in the event of a natural disaster. This past November, Campbell presented the Verizon Innovative App Challenge to the students, all of whom had excelled in computer science courses at Archmere, such as a class taught by Campbell called "App Development," and encouraged them to enter. A stipulation of the challenge is that students must develop "an original mobile app concept that incorporates STEM and addresses a need or problem in their school or community."

The team is now eligible for Best in Region Honors, which would earn them a $5,000 grant for the school and virtual coding training from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Media Lab development experts. If they win, they also would advance to the national-level competition, which brings a $15,000 grant and tablet computers. Winning the national-level competition would mean seeing coNextGen come to life. Verizon plans to release the results of the regional-level competition this February.

Jan. 20 was Catholic Schools Week and Bishop Malooly celebrated Mass with students and later in the week, the students closed a spirited week with cake along with an assembly. Students held a bake sale to raise money for Blue-Gold and the Special Olympics. Students also bought T-shirts with the proceeds also supporting Blue Gold. Students wore these shirts to Thursday's basketball game against St. Mark's.

Kendall Aulen

Caravel

Junior Brooke Dawson's debut single, "The Right Way," recently placed second in an Australian songwriter contest and was eligible for the 2013 "Homey Award" on WSTW. Brooke also recently aired on national television on an episode of "The Haunting Of."

Juniors Victoria Edwards and Olivia Kwiatkowski have works that will be featured in the 2013 Excellence in Drawing for the Delaware Foundation for the Visual Arts Calendar.

Fairwinds Christian

Last week, students participated in the annual Spirit Week. Each day was based off a game. For example; Monday was the game of Life. On that day, the students came dressed as lawyers, nurses, chefs and other occupations. The Candyland themed Tuesday had all the students arriving to school dressed as candy canes, Skittles, M&Ms, mints and other candy. On Wednesday was the game Battleship with students dressed as the men and women that serve the country or as police officers, firemen and others who help protect our nation. Thursday was school color day so students were dressed in green, gold and white accesories and clothes. Lastly, fancy Friday encouraged all students to come in nice appropriate dress clothes.

Many basketball games have been played. On Jan. 24 there were away games against Milford and on Jan. 28th home games against Fairton. There were also junior varsity and varisty boy and girl basketball home games against the Falcons and Chestertown on Jan. 31. On Tuesday there was home games against Calvary. There are home games today, also against Calvary.

People can follow the school on Instagram @FCSKnights and like the Facebook page, Fairwinds Christian School.

Kara Gallaher

Padua

During last week's Catholic Schools Week/Spirit Week, Padua celebrated its four pillars: Spirituality, Scholarship, Service and Sisterhood. Monday was Spirituality Day, with a schoolwide scavenger hunt hosted by Campus Ministry. Tuesday was Scholarship Day, focusing on Community Homeroom and awards. Wednesday was Sisterhood Day, in which pairs or groups of friends dressed as twins. Thursday was Service Day and Teacher Appreciation Day. Friday was Spirit Day, with an afternoon Spirit Assembly and dress-down. In addition, Student Council raffled off an iPad mini, Padua gear, and gift cards for iTunes and Bath and Body Works.

The Polar Bear Plunge is a significant fundraiser for Special Olympics Delaware, an organization that supports people with cognitive disabilities. Padua has supported the initiatives of Special Olympics and Project Unify through its Project Unify and Blue Gold Clubs. Padua organized a Padua Plunge team to participate in Sunday's event.

The College Essay Writing Seminar began last week for all juniors. The College 101 course will begin Feb. 10. The course, offered by the Office of College Advisement, is designed to teach the juniors about the college process.

Students are in the process of selecting courses for the 2014-15 academic year. The Freshmen Scheduling Night was held Wednesday. Students and parents were provided with information in assisting with the course selection process. Freshmen, sophomores and their parents are encouraged to schedule college advisement meetings to discuss the courses they are projected to take.

All students enrolled in one or more advanced placement courses have received information regarding exam registration forms. Students with any questions should contact Mary McClory.

French Week will be Feb. 24-28. An artist from Kennett Design will visit 2 to 4 p.m. Feb. 26. Students can learn how to create a version of Van Gogh's "Starry Night." The afternoon also includes house-made crepes by French teachers Megan Boyle and Susan Burris.

Teachers Mike Sheehan and Chris Wills have been selected to present Padua's Advocacy Program for Success at the Canadian Positive Psychology Conference in Ottawa, Ontario, in July. They will discuss their experiences in developing the seven qualities of success and how these qualities improve academic performance and social interactions.

In collaboration with professor Keith Weigelt of University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business, Padua will offer a one-week entrepreneurship program this summer for interested students. Working closely with Team Business, Weigelt has created Entrepreneur in the Classroom, a program that teaches business literacy. Topics that will be covered include: business plan Ideas, competitive environments, sales and marketing, pricing strategies, operations, human resources, management and accounting. Students will collaborate in teams and develop skills through hands-on exercises. The class is scheduled for the week of July 7. Parents whose daughters are interested in participating should contact head of school Cindy Mann as soon as possible.

Nikki Rash

Salesianum

Snowy weather couldn't damper spirits during a fun Feast Week in honor of patron saint Francis de Sales. On Jan. 20, many students chose to spend the Martin Luther King Jr. Day holiday volunteering in the Wilmington and Philadelphia areas. On Jan. 21, students attended a Martin Luther King Jr. Day prayer service before the snow sent everyone home early. Jan. 22 was a snow day, canceling plans for a school trivia game.

The Feast Day of Francis de Sales was celebrated with a school Mass on Jan. 23. All seniors were given medals with St. Francis' image, to remind them that they carry his teachings with them wherever they go.

The week ended Jan. 24 with a high-energy pep rally honoring winter sports. A student-faculty basketball game and foul shooting contest were some of the highlights, and some alumni participated.

Sanford

"Annie" premieres at 6:30 tonight and features students from the lower, middle and upper schools. The show runs 7:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday and 2 p.m. Sunday. Tickets are $12 at the door.

Senior basketball player Alison Lewis exceeded the 1,000-point milestone during the The Warriors' success at the Boardwalk Classic in Wildwood, N.J. Lewis was honored at Sanford during a conference game last month. She will play basketball for Boston University Women's Basketball program next year on a full scholarship.

Several upper school students will perform in Delaware All-State Theatre's production of "The Drowsy Chaperone." Junior Jordan McMillan will play the title role. Senior Christopher Malafronti will playFeldzieg. Seniors Emily Malafronti and Emma Heberton and junior Kate Holden were selected for the ensemble. Clint Williams, Sanford Performing Arts chairman, will be the music director for the show. The performances will be at Tatnall on June 20-22 and 27-29.

Correction: Freshman Katie Curran earned a Silver Key in the Scholastic Arts competition for her digital art piece "Comic Lips."

Middle School Spelling Bee champion Lilly Allingham will participate in the State Spelling Bee at St. Mark's High School on March 1.

The Service Club held its annual Spaghetti Dinner in Quigley Dining Hall Jan 24. Students and their families enjoyed food served by Service Club members while watching musical performances by students. Proceeds from the dinner will go to Habitat for Humanity, Emily Bissell Hospital and other supported charities.

Brooke Finnicum

St. Elizabeth

As part of Catholic Schools Week, St. Elizabeth welcomed nearly 400 students from Diocesan middle schools and entertained them with a mini variety show. St. E ambassadors were taken to their middle school alma maters to ride buses back to St. E with the visitors.

Artwork by art instructor Jen Mrozek will be on display at the Redding Gallery of the City/County Building in Wilmington this month. An opening reception for the exhibition "Words of Love" is scheduled from 5:30 to 8 p.m. Friday.

The Corbi Drive ends Friday. School families and staff are asked to have their orders submitted by the end of the school day.

Anatomy classes will take a field trip on Friday to the Mutter Museum of the College of Physicians of Philadelphia. America's finest museum of medical history, the Mütter displays its collections of anatomical specimens, models, and medical instruments in a 19th-century "cabinet museum" setting. The goal of the museum is to help the public understand the mysteries and beauty of the human body while appreciating the history of diagnosis and treatment of disease.

An assembly will be held Monday at which the March 6 blood drive will be discussed.

Freshmen will select their courses for the next academic year on Monday.

"Breaking Glass," a play written by freshman Nikolas Hunter, has been chosen as one of the six finalist plays in the 2013-2014 Delaware Young Playwrights Festival sponsored by the Delaware Theatre Company. Finalists will participate in a series of playwriting workshops with professional theater artists from DTC to further refine their writing and ready their works for a public showcase performance on March 11 on the DTC stage.

St. Elizabeth High has offered academic scholarships to 34 students from area middle schools: Alfred G. Waters Middle School: Matthew Gray, Emily Gray; All Saints Catholic School: Brandon Dongfack, Danielle Eckton; Christ the Teacher Catholic School: Lorenzo Alafriz, Matthew Balbierer, Colby Corrozi, Isabel Durnan, Owen Fink, Joel Hafycz, Nicole Kirk, Rebecca Miller, Corey O'Donnell; H.B. duPont Middle School: Sarah Kunkle; Holy Angels School: Nicholas Kayatta; Immaculate Heart of Mary School: Francis Doran, Matthew Hurst, Brendan Wilhelm; P.S. duPont Middle School: Sarayu Sivaram; St. Edmond's Academy: Dylan Kirk; St. Elizabeth Middle School: Alena Boyer, Rebecca Gonzalez, Irene Hu, Emily Marvel, Abigail Thompson, Evelyn Welsh; St. John the Beloved School: Ava Stratton; St. Mary Magdalen: Karl Bryan, Liam Lehane; St. Peter the Apostle School: Reiley Bond; The Independence School: Adair Bartram, Eric Ziegler; Northley Middle School (Pa.): Rebecca Gomes; and St. Philomena Academy (Pa.): Elizabeth Brutsche.

Vincent DiLissio

St. Mark's

Call at least one week in advance to make a reservation for a Spartan for a Day visit Call Shustine Brooks in the admissions office at 757-8721.

The Parent Association's fourth annual Wine and Beer Tasting is from 7 to 10 p.m. Feb. 22 in the cafeteria.Cost is $10 in advance and $15 at the door. Tickets may be purchased online and through the main office. A few will be available at the door. For questions, contact Francis Corrigan at fcorrigan@stmarkshs.net.

The Spartan Athletic Club Concert and Auction will be held March 29. Listen to the sounds of Blue Label, led by former Burnt Sienna frontman Jefe. Contact S.A.C. committee members Brian Murray at btmurray@btmurray.net or Michele Mirabella at mirabella22@verizon.net, for information.

Freshman Sarah Eissmann and Lucie Melvin are recipients of the just-announced 2013 Michael C. Ferguson scholarship, which is based on high achievement on the Delaware Comprehensive Assessment System test taken in the eighth-grade. Eismann was a student at Newark Charter School and Melvin was a student at Shue-Medill Middle School. Both girls received the award for their outstanding reading scores.

On Jan. 11 freshman Madison Sycalik was recognized by the Delaware Pony Club, a local United States Pony Clubs chapter, for her achievements, volunteerism and perseverance in the face of adversity with its annual Lanzi Award. Sycalik has been a member of the DPC since age 6 and has represented the Delmarva Region at national championships three times in the past four years. She hopes to qualify and competing again for eventing in July 2014 in Lexington, Ky. Sycalik was named captain at last year's championships, despite being the youngest member of the team.

This past weekend, senior officers of the Student Council presented at the National Association of Secondary School Principals LEAD Conference in Washington. The LEAD Conferences offer experiential leadership skills development to students and advisers in student government, National Honor Society and National Junior Honor Society. Presenters included Executive President Luke Duchemin, Executive Treasurer David Alessandrini, Senior Vice President Matthew Sutton and Senior Treasurer Sarah Dombroski. Other students who attended include Kathryn Fish, Trevor Boulden, Jeffrey Pala, James Hamory, Matthew DiPietro, Allan Carlsen, Spencer Jones, Elizabeth Danberg and Chelsea Vincelette.

The annual Shakespeare Competition will be held at 10 a.m. Saturday. Questions should be directed to Anne Eanes.

Parent College Information Night will be held in the cafeteria from 7 to 9 p.m. Important details of the college application process will be discussed. This night is geared for juniors and their parents but underclassmen and their parents are welcome to attend. Contact Wayne Smeigh or Yvette Drazich in college placement for more information.

Registration for the class of 2018 was held Jan. 20. For information on registering, contact Matthew Evans, director of admissions, at 757-8723.

Jake Bertelson

Tatnall

On Jan. 28, the Board of Trustees and the Search Committee announced the appointment of Charles A. Tierney III as the school's ninth Head of School, to succeed Eric G. Ruoss effective July 1. Committee and board members reached a unanimous decision to appoint Tierney, citing his experience, passion for education and strong character.

Tierney joins Tatnall from Northfield Mount Hermon in Mount Hermon, Mass., where he is the assistant head of school. During his 16-year tenure, he has been responsible for curriculum development, fundraising initiatives, faculty oversight and management of a STEM-building task force. In addition, he recently served as Interim Head of School, with responsibility for the day-to-day operations of the school, including managing its $30 million annual operating budget and overseeing its $3.4 million annual fund.

Prior to working at NMH, he was director of studies at St. Stephen's School in Rome from 1996-98. He earned a bachelor's degree in history from Dartmouth College in 1985 and a master's in education from Columbia University as a Klingenstein Fellow in 1994.

The Political Action Club hosted Delaware Gov. Jack Markell Jan. 24. Over the past several months, the club has hosted several guest speakers as part of their "Speaking Truth into Politics" series to help increase knowledge about local, state and national government. Markell addressed how he became involved in politics and the role students play in civic engagement.

The School Coffee House is at 7 p.m. Friday at World Café Live at The Queen. Students, faculty and alumni will perform.

Tower Hill

The art exhibition "Threshold" opens on Friday in the Founders' Gallery. Hours are 6 to 8 p.m. and it will feature found-art sculptures and crafted paintings by Phillipa Beardsley and Mark Blavat. The show will remain on display through February.

The Jefferson Awards winners for November and December were Rachel Minkovitz and Taylor Reese. Minkovitz worked with two organizations, the St. Michael's school and nursery and at the Delaware Art Museum's summer art camp. In her 61 hours of service with St. Michael's, she worked with kindergarten, first- and second-graders in arts and crafts. At the art museum, she oversaw projects and monitored campers. Reese has given 92 hours to the Special Olympics, an organization she has worked with for the last seven years. She has facilitated, organized and scheduled matches for special olympics athletes and works diligently in all the tasks asked of her.

Zach Nitsche is the January Jefferson Awards winner as well as a DuPont Service Awards winner. Nitsche has given more than 100 hours to the first tee organization, which teaches young children golf. In addition, he has helped organize many events in the Tower Hill community such as the Blue-Gold fashion show and the dodgeball tournament. This along with Nitsche's "outstanding character and commitment to service" is why he also was awarded for the DuPont Service Award.

Junior Kalee Kennedy, senior Vanna Ramirez and junior Taylor Reese have been awarded Scholastic Writing awards. Kennedy's flash fiction story, "I am and I Love" won a gold key award and her flash fiction, "Whispers (Schizo)" won honorable mention. Ramirez's poem "Carnival of Dust" won a silver key award and her poem "When I Found a Curious Snail" won honorable mention. Reese's flash fiction "The Terminal" won honorable mention.

Spencer Johnson
